docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: At a time in history when America's young adults should be demanding wages that actually pay the rent, health insurance for the 45 million Americans who are uninsured, and financial aid for exploding tuition, our parents' solution is to give us handouts? Lauren Grabowski Brooklyn, April 20, 2006

headline.main: Welcome to NiceBank: No Fee, Extra Interest

docs.abstract: Lauren Grabowski letter, prompted by April 20 article on parents who continue to subsidize their adult children, asks if accepting parents' handouts is any kind of solution
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     At a time in history when America's young adults should be demanding wages that actually pay the rent, health insurance for the 45 million Americans who are uninsured, and financial aid for exploding tuition, our parents' solution...

docs.lead_paragraph: When Roger Toussaint, the transit workers' union president, leads a procession of chanting union members and labor leaders across the Brooklyn Bridge today on his way to a jail cell in Manhattan, it will be only the latest bizarre twist in a contract fight that never seems to end. ''We've seen some of the most complex and strange events that anyone has ever seen in a labor dispute,'' said Mr. Toussaint, who headed a 60-hour transit shutdown in December that forced many cold, disgruntled New Yorkers to walk across bridges themselves.
docs.abstract: News Analysis: New York City Transport Workers' Union Pres Roger Touissaint's journey to Tombs jail in lower Manhattan to begin 10-day sentence for heading illegal strike is latest twist in seemingly endless contract fight; some experts say jail sentence could turn Toussaint into martyr, clinching his re-election later this year in fractious union; yet another strange twist is fact that Attorney Gen Eliot Spitzer, who asked for fine against union and jailing of Toussaint, may become Governor Spitzer, responsible for approving $130 million pension deal that Metropolitan Transportation Authority has been rejecting; photo (M)
docs.snippet: In the latest bizarre twist in a contract fight that never seems to end, Roger Toussaint will report to jail today.

docs.lead_paragraph: With a deadline looming in just three weeks, Medicare drug plans are expecting a surge of new enrollment that threatens to overwhelm already busy phone lines and leave beneficiaries struggling to figure out how to sign up for the new plan. The telephone complications are among the latest round of problems that have left thousands of beneficiaries with large belated premium payments and raised questions about whether insurers are complying with federal standards.

headline.main: Deadline Near, Jams Are Seen For Drug Plan

docs.snippet: Medicare drug plans expect a surge of new enrollment that threatens to overwhelm already busy phone lines.

docs.lead_paragraph: BY day, Shawn Beyer teaches English as a second language at Sag Harbor Elementary School. By night, she teaches adults. Her fiancé, Dan Mitchell, works as a chef. Between them, they earn $70,000 a year. To save for a house, for the last two years they have been splitting the $1,833-a-month rent for a two-bedroom, one-bathroom house in Sag Harbor with Ms. Beyer's twin, Shannon, and her boyfriend, Duane McMahon, a cabinetmaker and landscaper.

headline.main: East End Blues: Working Hard And Unable To Buy a Home

docs.abstract: Long Island Journal column on difficulties many young working families face in finding affordable houses to buy on Long Island's East End; Long Island Index shows those in 20- to 34-year-old age bracket are leaving Island in droves; situation is particularly acute on East End, where $600,000 barely buys fixer-upper and where about half the houses are second homes, not suitable for year-round living; photos (M)
docs.snippet: BY day, Shawn Beyer teaches English as a second language at Sag Harbor Elementary School. By night, she teaches adults. Her fiancé, Dan Mitchell, works as a chef. Between them, they earn $70,000 a year.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE voice of Mike Gallagher boomed, godlike, in the air. Red lights flickered on a broadcasting console at the radio studio. ''Hello? Hello?'' he said. ''One, two, three.''

headline.main: The Beating Pulse of the 18th Floor

docs.abstract: Article describes day in varied offices on typical floor of Empire State Building, which is celebrating its 75th anniversary; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Radio days, poetry-fueled nights and, in between, a little Organic Tummy Joy. This is a typical floor in the Empire State Building.

docs.lead_paragraph: AVOID all travel to the Gaza Strip, a travel warning from the federal Department of State says. Avoid the West Bank, it says, and really, go to Israel only if necessary. Since the Palestinian Authority's elections Jan. 25 in which Hamas won a majority of seats, ''Israeli authorities are concerned about a possible increase in suicide bombings in Israel,'' says the warning, which proved to be well founded last week. Precarious or not, Israel is high on the list of spring 2007 study-abroad options for Nathan Kamens, a sophomore pre-med major at the University of Connecticut in Storrs. Mr. Kamens said he isn't worried about suicide bombers, or anything else.
docs.abstract: Article on increasing number of students attending colleges in Connecticut who choose to study abroad in any of 26 countries despite travel warnings from US State Department; School for International Training, which runs study-abroad programs in 60 countries, says more than 200,000 American students are studying abroad this year, almost 20 percent increase since 9/11; Mary Devins of Connecticut College says study abroad is no longer limited to students whose parents are wealthy and that many students choose colleges based partly on their study-abroad offerings; photos (L)
docs.snippet: An increasing number of students in Connecticut are choosing to study abroad in any of the 26 countries on the federal State Department's travel warning list.
docs.section_name: Travel; Education; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Dov Charney's office, in the corner of the top floor of American Apparel's factory headquarters in downtown Los Angeles -- like American Apparel retail locations around the world, like Charney's house in nearby Echo Park and his apartment on the Lower East Side of New York, like Charney's mind itself -- is a colorful, cluttered, retro-themed and stimulating place. Strewn around the vintage 1970's couches, you're likely to see an assortment of fabric scraps and prototype T-shirts beside samples of unusual light bulbs that Charney wants to test for store displays. On his desk sit copies of Playboy from the 1980's, their pages carefully annotated and tabbed with colored stickers denoting their depiction of socks, pants, T-shirts, electronics, car designs and other markers of style from the period. Next to these is a stack of come-on letters from television and film casting directors hoping to get Charney to supply them with the kind of fresh and unusual faces on display in American Apparel's provocative print ads. Further over you'll find some books that Charney has been consulting, including a collection of Andy Warhol's early hand-painted works; ''The Concise 48 Laws of Power,'' by Robert Greene; and ''The Medium Is the Massage,'' by Charney's fellow Canadian Marshall McLuhan. Pinned to the rear wall is some classic National Geographic-style cheesecake: pages ripped from a 1975 ''Girls of Polynesia'' calendar. It's an element echoed in a handful of the American Apparel stores, which feature displays of original covers from erotic magazines from the 70's and 80's, including Oui and Penthouse, and also sell paperback photo collections of the work of Yasumasa Yonehara, a Japanese photographer working in the erotic snapshot tradition pioneered by Nobuyoshi Araki.

headline.main: And You Thought Abercrombie & Fitch Was Pushing It?

docs.abstract: Jaime Wolf profile of Dov Charney, man behind American Apparel, company noted for humane work environment at its factory in Los Angeles, its sexy T-shirts and briefs and highly suggestive ads; notes that 3,500 people who work at company's factory in Los Angeles--largest single garment factory in US--are paid at least twice minimum wage and receive subsidized health care, meals, free English lessons and regular massages; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Everyone knows sex sells clothing, but no one has taken that idea further than Dov Charney of American Apparel.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Jon S. Corzine may be a low-key, low-volume New Jersey chief executive, but state residents appear to be hearing him quite clearly. After years of blaring headlines about corrupt politicos, Mr. Corzine won the support of many New Jerseyans because his soft-spoken demeanor and button-down Wall Street résumé seemed to offer a long overdue chance to hit the mute button.

headline.main: Little Comfort for Corzine In School Budget Rejections

docs.abstract: David Kocieniewski Politics column on negative political impact that voter rejection of many school budgets may have on New Jersey's soft-spoken Gov Jon Corzine; holds Corzine's proposed citizen's property-tax commission and rollback of state's school financing formula are unlikely to happen (M)
docs.snippet: Gov. Jon S. Corzine may be a low-key, low-volume New Jersey chief executive, but state residents appear to be hearing him quite clearly.     After years of blaring headlines about corrupt politicos, Mr. Corzine won the support of many New Jerseyans...
